contextId.information: This idiom refers to a captain who is in charge of fifty soldiers. It can be translated with a more general term. AT: "the army officer" or "the military leader" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This phrase means "let us marry you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "falls into" is an idiom that means to become something worse. AT: "the land becomes a desolate waste" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: the land falls into a desolate waste

contextId.information: "When Ahaz ... was king of Judah" This was when the events happened. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: During the days of Ahaz ... king of Judah

contextId.information: "Yahweh spoke to me in a very powerful way" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh spoke to me, with his strong hand upon me

contextId.information: "Send a word" means to speak. AT: "The Lord has spoken against the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: The Lord sent a word against Jacob, and it fell on Israel

contextId.information: The phrase "stir up" is an idiom that means to incite them to attack. AT: "and Yahweh will cause Israel's enemies to attack" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: and will stir up his enemies

contextId.information: Giving light represents "shining." AT: "will not shine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The phrase "generation to generation" refers to all generations of people who will live in the future. AT: "for ever" "ever again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Looking toward God here represents hoping that he will help them. AT: "men will hope that their Maker, the Holy One of Israel, will help them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: men will look toward their Maker ... will look to the Holy One of Israel

contextId.information: This is an idiom. Here silence is meant to signal shock and amazement. AT: "Be shocked"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The phrase "lift up their voices" is an idiom that means to speak loudly. AT: "They will sing and shout about the majesty of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: They will lift up their voices and shout the majesty of Yahweh

contextId.information: This idiom means the person has the authority to judge. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Here "to turn back" is an idiom that means to defeat in battle. AT: "and Yahweh will cause the soldiers to be strong so that they defeat their enemies when the enemies attack their city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: and strength for those who turn back their enemies at their gates

contextId.information: This is an idiom that means to distort what is true. AT: "You make things opposite of the way they should be" or "You distort the truth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom that means to trust or rely on something. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here the word "bring" means to "cause." AT: "he will cause disasters to happen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The phrase "called out against it" means to be sent out to chase the lion away. This can be stated in active form. AT: "when someone sends shepherds to chase the lion away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] or [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: when a group of shepherds is called out against it

contextId.information: This word is used here to draw peoples' attention to what is said next. AT: "Listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This word is used here to draw peoples' attention to what is said next. It is also used here to mark a new section in the book. AT: "Listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here walking refers to living. AT: "He who lives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "day" is an idiom for a point in time; it is not a literal "day." AT: "it will be the time when Yahweh gets revenge" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: it will be a day of vengeance for Yahweh

contextId.information: Sennacherib uses this idiom to draw Hezekiah's attention to what he says next. AT: "Listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The idiom "to speak in someone's ear" means to speak where they can hear you. AT: "where the people who are on the wall may hear us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: in the ears of the people who are on the wall

contextId.information: This idiom means to agree officially to act peacefully towards one another. AT: "Let us agree to have peace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The phrase "put a spirit in him" means that God will influence him to make a specific decision. The word "spirit" here means a strong attitude or feeling. AT: "I will influence him so that when he hears a certain report, he will go back to his own land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: I will put a spirit in him, and he will hear a certain report and go back to his own land

contextId.information: The phrase "fall by the sword" is an idiom that means that his enemy will kill him with a sword. AT: "And there in his own land, I will cause his enemies to kill him with their swords" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: I will cause him to fall by the sword in his own land

contextId.information: This is an idiom. The word "see" here is used to add emphasis to what is said next. AT: "You have certainly heard" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means to have authority and to rule over all the kingdoms. AT: "have authority over all the kingdoms" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means to kill. AT: "killing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This is an idiom. Here "walk" means to "live." The phrase means to live in a way the pleases Yahweh. AT: "faithfully lived before you" or "faithfully served you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This is an idiom that is used to introduce something that God told his prophets or his people. AT: "Yahweh spoke this message" or "Yahweh spoke these words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. Yahweh uses this word to draw the listener's attention to what is said next. AT: "Listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This word is used here as an idiom to draw Hezekiah's attention to what is said next. AT: "Listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This refers to Babylon's false sense of security in thinking that she will never lose her position of wealth and honor. AT: "who think you are safe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Possible meanings are 1) that this is a literal expression of submission where the person licks the dust off of a superior's foot or from the ground at the superior's foot or 2) that this is an idiom that describes a person prostrating himself before a superior. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: lick the dust of your feet

contextId.information: Here the word "hot" means "strong" or "great." AT: "great fury" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. AT: "shout loudly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The phrase "shut their mouths" is an idiom. AT: "kings will stop talking" or "kings will be silent" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. AT: "causes trouble" or "troubles you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means God gave up on his people and no longer helped or blessed them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

"Break open" is an idiom that means when a light begins to shine brightly. This means that if they help people in need, their deeds will be like lights others will see, as when the sun comes up after a dark night. Or the light may refer to the light of the Lord, shining on them and blessing them. (See:  [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Then your light would be broken open like the sunrise

contextId.information: This is an idiom that means "remember." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"Spreading out my hands" is a person's gesture to show imploring or a strong request. AT: "I have continually begged a stubborn people to receive my help." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: I have spread out my hands all day to a stubborn people

contextId.information: This means God will punish them to the fullest extent. This expression compares Yahweh punishing the people to dumping on their legs as they are sitting. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
